Comment: Hi all; here's a brief by-request annotation of a recent game. This particular game shows how one small mistake early on can cascade into an unwinnable position over the course of the game. Enjoy!
I've been playing the Latvian Gambit in these games. It makes for very sharp, decisive play, where the game may hang in the balance on every move.
I've been playing the Latvian Gambit in these games. It makes for very sharp, decisive play, where the game may hang in the balance on every move.
I've been playing the Latvian Gambit in these games. It makes for very sharp, decisive play, where the game may hang in the balance on every move.
Too passive a continuation for my tastes, but safer than the main lines (3.Nxe5, 3.Bc4, 3.exf4, 3.d4).
A waiting move. This Knight frequently proves hard to develop in this opening, so I prefer to get it into play early.
White's play is solid, if passive. This Bishop usually develops to g5 (or beyond!)

Inaccurate, but not deadly by any means. This move doesn't have any real effect except to hinder White's QN's development. As I mentioned earlier, d2-d4 was playable all the way back at move 3; it didn't need support.

Inaccurate, but not deadly by any means. This move doesn't have any real effect except to hinder White's QN's development. As I mentioned earlier, d2-d4 was playable all the way back at move 3; it didn't need support.
Black continues development while pressuring the White center.
? And here, suddenly, unexpectedly, White throws away a piece with a subtle mistake. The thing to notice is that with this move, White's Bishop is trapped.
And now Black wins the Bishop for a pawn. It's worth mentioning right now, I think, that White's play is very solid for the rest of the game. 6.Nbd2 was the only real mistake.
I like 8.Be2 better; this doesn't serve much of a purpose and loses a move.
I like 8.Be2 better; this doesn't serve much of a purpose and loses a move.
I like 8.Be2 better; this doesn't serve much of a purpose and loses a move.
White looks like he's planning to go kingside, so Black prepares to castle queenside and aims a battery toward the WK along the c8-h3 diagonal.
White looks like he's planning to go kingside, so Black prepares to castle queenside and aims a battery toward the WK along the c8-h3 diagonal.

White looks like he's planning to go kingside, so Black prepares to castle queenside and aims a battery toward the WK along the c8-h3 diagonal.
White looks like he's planning to go kingside, so Black prepares to castle queenside and aims a battery toward the WK along the c8-h3 diagonal.
White's play is a little scattered, but not at all bad. Here he begins to make queenside threats, to discourage Black from castling.
Shoring up the weak pawn.
White's plans begin to take form; he piles up on the Nc6.

There's no real need to deal with the queenside pressure yet, so Black offers a trade. Normally it's disadvantageous to trade a good Bishop for a bad one (as here), but Black is following a single very simple principle: when ahead in material (especially by a whole piece), trade pieces.
Even the best place for Black's extra Bishop isn't great right now with so much mass on the board, so he aims it at the White Knight to create pressure.
Even the best place for Black's extra Bishop isn't great right now with so much mass on the board, so he aims it at the White Knight to create pressure.
Even the best place for Black's extra Bishop isn't great right now with so much mass on the board, so he aims it at the White Knight to create pressure.
Even the best place for Black's extra Bishop isn't great right now with so much mass on the board, so he aims it at the White Knight to create pressure.
White defends.
Black finally blocks up the WQ's pressure on a7, and as a result lessens the burden on c6 as well.
Defending b7 and getting the last Rook into play.
Defending b7 and getting the last Rook into play.
White drives off this pesky Knight, though there is danger to remember when pushing pawns in front of your King--especially when the opponent already has advanced pawns to poke at the weakness.
